q: What are the signs of an ingrown toenail?
a: Signs of an ingrown toenail include redness, pain, swelling, and the toenail curving into the toe.

q: How can I treat an ingrown toenail at home?
a: You can soak your foot in warm, salty water, keep your foot dry, wear wide and comfortable shoes, and take pain relievers like paracetamol or ibuprofen.

q: When should I see a GP for an ingrown toenail?
a: You should see a GP if treating your ingrown toenail at home is not helping, the toe is painful and swollen with pus coming out of it, you have a high temperature or you feel hot or shivery, or if you have diabetes and an ingrown toenail.

q: What treatments can a GP provide for an ingrown toenail?
a: A GP can check your toe and provide antibiotics if the toenail is infected. If the ingrown toenail is severe, you may be referred to a foot specialist (podiatrist).

q: What treatments can a foot specialist offer for an ingrown toenail?
a: A foot specialist may cut away part of the nail or remove the whole nail. Local anesthesia is used to numb the toe during these treatments.

q: Are there any ways to prevent ingrown toenails?
a: To prevent ingrown toenails, avoid cutting your toenails too short, cut them straight across rather than at the edges, wear properly fitting shoes, and keep your feet clean and dry.

q: What are the symptoms of an infected ingrown toenail?
a: Symptoms of an infected ingrown toenail include pus coming out of the toe and feeling hot or shivery.

q: Can a pharmacist help with an ingrown toenail?
a: Yes, a pharmacist can provide treatments to ease the pain and prevent infection. They can also advise if you need to see a GP.

q: Is NHS referral to a podiatrist available for everyone?
a: NHS referral to a podiatrist may not be available to everyone and waiting times can be long. You can choose to see a podiatrist privately.

q: What type of shoes should I avoid wearing to prevent ingrown toenails?
a: You should avoid wearing shoes that are too tight or do not fit properly to prevent ingrown toenails.
